metadata.sermon_start_end: As you know, the ethnic Albanians of Kosovo are mostly Muslims. It was reported in the news media that Serbian Orthodox paramilitary personnel were threatening some of these Muslim Kosovars with death if they did not make the sign of the cross. We need to take this very deeply to heart. [...] When we truly understand this, when it sinks into our hearts, we will be overwhelmed with gratitude. If we truly understand what God has done for us this day, we will be seized by the desire to thank and praise him. That is our part, this Good Friday.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon identifies Galatians 3:10-14 as the core. It attempts to find the specific 'scandal' of the text—the curse of the tree. However, it relies heavily on other scriptures (Isaiah, Matthew, Corinthians) to explain it, somewhat diluting the unique voice of the Galatians passage.
quotes: this passage from Galatians gives us the most succinct and compelling view of what Jesus did on the Cross
Verse 13: 'Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law, having become a curse for us'
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus more exclusively on why Paul uses the 'curse' terminology specifically in the context of the Law's failure, rather than harmonizing it so quickly with John 3:16 or Isaiah 53.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher acknowledges the Old Testament roots (Deuteronomy) and the logic of Paul's argument. However, the 'exposition' is brief and lacks the depth of Hebrew/Greek nuance Dekker demands. It explains the 'what' but stays on the surface of the 'how' of the first-century context.
quotes: In the book of Deuteronomy, which Paul is quoting, God promises blessings...
He has been rereading a passage in Deuteronomy that said a dead body should not be displayed publicly
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the exegesis of the 'curse of the law'—what did this mean specifically for a first-century Jew under the Torah versus the Gentile Galatians?

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application starts concretely with the Kosovo conflict but then retreats into generalities about 'us all' and 'miserable offenders.' It lacks the sharp, contemporary cultural philosophy or sociological 'zeitgeist' analysis Dekker expects.
quotes: If you know that you are a 'miserable offender' against God's goodness, then you are already in a state of grace.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond the Kosovo illustration to show how the 'curse of the law' functions in modern secular or religious 'laws' that people fail to keep today.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is somewhat fragmented. It begins with news events, moves to a hymn, then to the text, then back to dogma. The 'movement' where the hearer is 'expounded' together with the text is interrupted by these shifts.
quotes: Let us turn our attention again to the section of Galatians that was read just now
I ask you now to pay very close attention to the words of the hymn
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the contemporary examples (the trial, the soldiers) directly into the verse-by-verse exposition of the curse and substitution.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: This is a strong point. The sermon explicitly follows the structure of misery (the curse/inability to keep the law), redemption (substitution), and gratitude (the response). It avoids over-objectification by addressing the hearer's state.
quotes: we are constitutionally unable to keep God's law
Christ redeemed us from the curse
we will be overwhelmed with gratitude
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: The 'misery' could be more psychologically acute; it remains somewhat forensic and legalistic.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon mentions the possibility of perishing and the 'rightful wrath of God,' which aligns with the 'two ways.' However, it softens the blow by suggesting the audience is 'already in a state of grace' just by being there.
quotes: If you are aware that you do not measure up... then you are already God's person.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Avoid the 'liberal' trap of making the outcome feel safe too early; let the threat of the curse be felt more poignantly before the resolution.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon emphasizes the substitutionary work and the Trinitarian nature of the Cross, avoiding a 'vengeful father' caricature. It correctly identifies Christ as the only source of life.
quotes: The Father and the Son are accomplishing our redemption together
Jesus absorbs into himself the rightful wrath of God
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure the 'substitution' doesn't become a general 'idea' but remains tied to the specific 'crabbed' logic of the Galatians text.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1,100 words, the sermon would take about 11 minutes. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for 'depth.' It is more of a meditation than a full sermon.
quotes: I can't do full justice to their complexity here
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition and the contemporary application to meet the minimum 20-minute threshold required for substantive preaching.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short primarily in its brevity and its tendency to rely on general theological truths rather than the specific, unique 'scandal' of the Galatians text. While it follows the three-part structure of the Catechism well, it lacks the exegetical depth and the 20-minute 'breadth' that Dekker demands for a sermon to be truly 'substantive.'
strengths: Clear Trinitarian framing of the atonement, avoiding crude penal substitution theories.
Effective use of the Misery-Redemption-Gratitude triad as a background structure.
Strong focus on Christ as the telos of the message.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (approx. 11 minutes) to achieve the necessary homiletical depth.
The application is occasionally general ('you and me') rather than concrete and contemporary.
The exegesis of the 'curse' is present but lacks the rigorous humanities-based 'exposition' Dekker requires.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate meditation, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the full sense of Dekker’s definition. It lacks the necessary breadth (time) and the specific, 'nowhere else' exegetical sharpness required to recreate the Bible into a current, proclamatory word.
